recommendations.option: Encourage another behavior to take the place of your child’s hurtful behavior
subOption: Gives your child attention
Let’s children know what they can do, not just what they can’t

recommendations.option: For hitting/pushing/pulling hair, say “Use your hands to throw a ball, help me clean up the house, or build Legos.”
For kicking, say “Kicking is not OK! You can use your feet to jump up and down. If you are feeling mad, you can stomp your feet.”
For biting, say “Use your teeth to eat food.”
For language that is hurtful, say “Let’s think about better words to use the next time we are angry.”
Redirecting helps a child learn acceptable ways to respond to life’s challenges
In the long run, it can make matters worse
Spanking is associated with many health problems
It does not make sense to teach a child not to hit by hitting them
There are better options
Some people have heard, “Spare the rod, spoil the child”
subOption: However, shepherds used a rod to guide sheep, not hit them
Spare the rod but not the guidance

recommendations.option: Because there are better options, spanking is not recommended

title: Set the rule by firmly saying “No Hitting.”

recommendations.option: Children want to know what is allowed.
Get down on eye level
Use firm voice
Use short response
Do not use more than 1-2 times in short period

title: Later, praise your child for playing nicely

recommendations.option: Catch your child being good
When your child plays nicely, tell them!
“You are doing a good job playing with your brother”
If you praise frequently, your child will listen better

title: Ask your child how the other child feels

recommendations.option: Ask questions about the feelings of the person who was hurt
subOption: “How does it feel when someone hits you?”
“Do you think he likes being hit?”
“How does it feel when you hit others?”
“Let’s go ask him how it felt when you hit him.”

recommendations.option: Some children will make excuses
subOption: Keep the focus on the hurtful behavior.
“It does not matter if you did not mean it…your behavior caused someone to feel hurt.”

recommendations.option: Caring for yourself and others is a balancing act

title: Place your child in time-out
option: A good option after others have been tried

recommendations.option: Not recommended for children < 3 years
Use infrequently
1 minute for every year of age
Keep it brief
“You are in time out to think about not hurting, and how to do something helpful with your hands.”

recommendations.option: Not effective in the long run

OK to say, “I am pretty upset right now and I need to take a break”

recommendations.option: Think of the behavior as bad, or hurtful, but not the child
Everyone behaves badly from time to time
Give your child the strong message that they can grow up to do very positive things with their life

title: Leave the area
option: A good option after others have been tried

recommendations.option: Before the next public outing, let your child know that you are serious about good behavior in public
If your child does not behave, leave or take your child away from the area
As you leave, explain why
“When you hurt other people, we both miss out on what we wanted to do.”

title: Discuss why hurtful behavior is wrong

recommendations.option: You can talk about “why” in simple terms, even when children are young
Eventually, you want your child to not hurt others because he understands why hurtful behavior is wrong, not because you told him not to hurt others
“Don’t hurt others just because I told you not to– it is actually in your best interest to not hurt others.”
“The world is a great place to live because most people have learned how to get things done without hurting others.”
“You like to build things…will you ever be able to finish any big projects if you cannot get along with others?”
“You like sports…how many championships will you be able to win if your team members do not listen to each other?”
Discussions about “why” will decrease aggression and open lines of communication
Occasionally, everybody chooses inappropriate ways to respond to life’s challenges
Teach how they can respond without hurting anyone
subOption: Words
Eye contact
Other body language

recommendations.option: “Next time, I expect you to make a better choice such as using your words”

title: Role play at another time
option: A good option after others have been tried

recommendations.option: Everyone needs practice
Role play can be a great option () if the challenging behaviors are always at school
Role play is practice for a stressful event

Example: “I want to help you solve problems without hurting others. Let’s practice until we get it right.  Pretend I am one of your classmates and I take your pencil, making you upset.  What are you going to do?  Are you going to push me down and kick me? Or, are you going to say in a firm voice with good eye contact, ‘That pencil is mine, you need to find your own,’ or ‘That pencil is mine, I will let you borrow it after I am done.’ Let’s practice.  Show me what you will do.”
With frequent role play, adults may not need to be involved
Role play can teach your child the important life lesson of how to solve problems their own

title: Change your daily schedule
option: A good option after others have been tried

recommendations.option: A great option () for children who have ongoing behavior problems
Everybody needs extra support from time to time
Change your schedule to help your child through rough periods
Listen to your child’s needs, fears, and concerns
Spend time to redirect behaviors and have discussions
Put your cell phone away and have good eye contact
Prevent problem behaviors from getting out of control
